connections.description: Features a sand floor, one of only two remaining sand-floor synagogues in the world.

connections.name: Curaao Jewish history
connections.description: Curaao Jews were instrumental in the island's trade economy from the 17th century.

Tanzania.name: Jewish Community of Dar es Salaam
Tanzania.description: Small but historic Jewish community in Tanzania dating back to World War II-era refugees. The community maintains cultural connections and hosts Shabbat gatherings. Members include descendants of European refugees, Israeli expatriates, and foreign diplomats.

individuals.name: David Elias
individuals.bio: Coordinates Jewish community events and maintains connections with international Jewish organizations in East Africa.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Listed as an affiliate community under the WJC framework.

connections.relationship: Connected to international Jewish networks

Trinidad and Tobago.name: Caribbean Jewish Congress
Trinidad and Tobago.description: The Caribbean Jewish Congress represents the scattered but historically significant Jewish communities across the Caribbean islands. Jewish settlement in the Caribbean dates to the 1600s, making it among the oldest in the Americas. Sephardic Jews fleeing the Inquisition settled in Curacao (1651), Jamaica (1655), Barbados (1628), and other islands, establishing some of the oldest synagogues in the Western Hemisphere. These communities played crucial roles in the sugar, shipping, and trading industries that shaped the colonial Caribbean. Today the Caribbean Jewish population is small but maintains historic synagogues and congregations in Jamaica, Curacao, Trinidad, US Virgin Islands, Barbados, and other islands.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Both are Jewish representative organizations

connections.name: Hebrew Congregation of St. Thomas
connections.description: One of the historic congregations in the Caribbean network.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Represents Caribbean Jewry internationally.

Botswana.name: Jewish Community of Botswana
Botswana.description: The Jewish Community of Botswana is an extremely small community in southern Africa, numbering only a few families, mostly South African Jews and Israeli expatriates involved in Botswana's diamond industry, development work, and business. Botswana is the world's largest producer of diamonds by value, and De Beers (which has significant Jewish connections through the Oppenheimer family) has been the country's primary diamond mining partner since independence. Israeli diamond dealers and polishers have been active in Botswana's diamond sector, and Israel has maintained diplomatic and economic relations with Botswana. The community gathers for major Jewish holidays and maintains connections to the larger South African Jewish community across the border. Botswana has been one of the more Israel-friendly nations in Africa, maintaining quiet but consistent diplomatic relations.

individuals.name: Avner Tzur
individuals.role: Community leader and Israeli ambassador liaison

connections.name: De Beers / Oppenheimer family
connections.description: De Beers, with Jewish connections through the Oppenheimers, is the primary diamond mining partner in Botswana.

connections.name: Israeli diamond industry
connections.description: Israeli diamond dealers and polishers are active in Botswana's diamond sector.

connections.name: South African Jewish community
connections.description: Botswana's Jews are connected to the larger South African Jewish community.

Belarus.name: Union of Belarusian Jewish Public Associations and Communities
Belarus.description: Representative body of Belarusian Jews. Belarus was a major center of Jewish life before WWII, home to cities like Minsk, Brest, and Pinsk with large Jewish populations. Approximately 10,000-20,000 Jews remain.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Both are Jewish representative organizations

connections.relationship: Belarusian member of WJC

Kazakhstan.name: Jewish Community of Kazakhstan
Kazakhstan.description: The Jewish Community of Kazakhstan represents approximately 3,000-5,000 Jews in Central Asia's largest country. Kazakhstan's Jewish history includes both ancient Bukharian Jewish trading communities along the Silk Road and a significant wave of Soviet-era Jews who were evacuated or deported to Kazakhstan during World War II. During the Holocaust, Kazakhstan served as a place of refuge for hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews evacuated from Nazi-advancing areas, effectively saving their lives. In the post-Soviet era, most of Kazakhstan's Jews emigrated to Israel, Germany, or the United States. The remaining community, centered in Almaty and Nur-Sultan (Astana), is active and maintains synagogues and community centers. Kazakhstan under President Nazarbayev maintained positive relations with Israel while also engaging the broader Muslim world. The community is supported by Chabad and the Alexander Baron Jewish Community Center of Kazakhstan.

connections.name: Kazakh Jewish community
connections.description: Approximately 3,500 Jews live in Kazakhstan, mostly in Almaty and Nur-Sultan.

connections.name: Chabad of Kazakhstan
connections.description: Chabad provides religious services and community support across Kazakhstan.

Indonesia.name: Surabaya Jewish Community
Indonesia.description: The Jewish Community of Surabaya, Indonesia, represents a nearly extinct community that was once the largest in Southeast Asia's most populous country. Surabaya's Jews, primarily Baghdadi and Dutch Sephardic traders, settled in the city during the Dutch colonial era. The community built a synagogue and maintained a cemetery. At its peak in the 1920s-1930s, the community numbered several hundred. The Japanese occupation during World War II disrupted the community, and Indonesian independence and subsequent political changes led to the departure of most Jews. Today the community is essentially defunct, with the former synagogue building repurposed. The Jewish cemetery in Surabaya remains as one of the few physical traces of what was once a thriving community.

connections.name: Indonesian Jewish heritage
connections.description: Surabaya had a small Jewish community from Dutch colonial times; the synagogue still stands.

connections.name: Dutch East Indies history
connections.description: Jews came to Indonesia with Dutch colonial merchants in the 17th-19th centuries.

Iceland.name: Icelandic Jewish Community
Iceland.description: The Icelandic Jewish Community is one of Europe's smallest, numbering approximately 100-250 people on this North Atlantic island nation. Iceland' Jewish history is minimal - a small number of Jewish merchants and refugees arrived in the 19th and early 20th centuries. During the Holocaust, Iceland (then under Danish sovereignty) had a complex relationship with Jewish refugees. Today's community is largely composed of Jewish immigrants and their families, plus Israeli expatriates. Iceland's relationship with Israel has been notable: in 2011, Iceland became one of the first Western countries to recognize Palestinian statehood, straining relations with Israel. In 2018, the Icelandic parliament debated banning circumcision, which the Jewish community and Anti-Defamation League strongly opposed as a threat to religious freedom. The community gathers informally for holidays and is supported by visiting rabbis. Reykjavik is likely the world's most northern city with an organized Jewish presence.

individuals.name: Michael Fel
individuals.role: President of the Jewish Association of Iceland

connections.name: Circumcision ban debate
connections.description: Iceland's 2018 debate on banning circumcision was viewed as a threat to Jewish religious freedom.

connections.name: Palestinian recognition
connections.description: Iceland was one of the first Western countries to recognize Palestinian statehood in 2011.

connections.name: Nordic Jewish communities
connections.description: Connected to the small Jewish communities across Scandinavia.

Democratic Republic of the Congo.name: Jewish Community of Lubumbashi
Democratic Republic of the Congo.description: The Jewish Community of Lubumbashi in the Democratic Republic of the Congo represents one of sub-Saharan Africa's most unusual Jewish stories. Lubumbashi (formerly Elisabethville) attracted Jewish settlers in the early 20th century, drawn by the mineral wealth of the Katanga region. At its peak in the 1950s, the community numbered several hundred, primarily Sephardic Jews from Rhodes and Ashkenazi Jews from Belgium and Eastern Europe. They established a synagogue, cemetery, and community institutions. After Congolese independence in 1960 and subsequent political instability, most Jews departed. Today only a handful remain, but the community buildings and cemetery still stand as testimony to this little-known chapter of African Jewish history.

individuals.name: Benoit Mbuyi
individuals.role: Leader of the Lubumbashi Jewish community

connections.name: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee
connections.description: JDC provided support to small African Jewish communities.

connections.relationship: Connected to international Jewish organizational network

Barbados.name: Nidhe Israel Synagogue
Barbados.description: Historic synagogue in Bridgetown, Barbados. One of the oldest synagogues in the Western Hemisphere. Sephardic Jews played a major role in establishing the sugar industry. The mikveh was rediscovered in 2008.

individuals.name: Paul Altman
individuals.role: President of the Barbados Jewish community

connections.name: Barbados Jewish heritage
connections.description: One of the oldest synagogues in the Western Hemisphere, dating to 1654.

connections.name: Sephardic colonial history
connections.description: Built by Sephardic Jews who fled the Inquisition to the Caribbean.

U.S. Virgin Islands.name: Hebrew Congregation of St. Thomas
U.S. Virgin Islands.description: The Hebrew Congregation of St. Thomas in the US Virgin Islands maintains one of the oldest synagogues in continuous use in the Western Hemisphere. The Beracha Veshalom Vegmiluth Hasadim synagogue was founded in 1796 by Sephardic Jews who settled on the island during the Danish colonial era. The synagogue features a distinctive sand floor, said to symbolize the desert wanderings of the Israelites and the secret worship of conversos during the Inquisition. Charlotte Amalie was once a major Jewish commercial center, and the community played a significant role in Caribbean trade. The artist Camille Pissarro was born into the St. Thomas Jewish community in 1830. Today the congregation serves approximately 100-150 community members plus many Jewish tourists.

connections.name: Caribbean Jewish Congress
connections.description: Part of the network of Caribbean Jewish communities.

connections.name: American Jewish Historical Society
connections.description: Connected as one of the oldest Jewish congregations in the Americas.

Tajikistan.name: Jewish Community of Dushanbe
Tajikistan.description: The Jewish Community of Dushanbe represents the remnant of what was once a significant Bukharian Jewish community in Tajikistan. Bukharian Jews, who spoke a Judeo-Persian dialect, had lived in Central Asia for over 2,000 years, with legends tracing their origin to the Babylonian exile. Before the Soviet era, Dushanbe and other Central Asian cities had vibrant Jewish communities. The Soviet period suppressed religious practice but preserved the communities. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, and particularly during the Tajik Civil War (1992-1997), the vast majority of Tajikistan's Jews emigrated to Israel, the United States, and other countries. Today, only a few dozen to a few hundred Jews remain in Dushanbe. The community maintains a synagogue and is supported by Chabad. Tajikistan's Jewish community represents the decline of the ancient Bukharian Jewish civilization of Central Asia.

connections.name: Bukharan Jewish heritage
connections.description: Tajikistan's Jews are mostly of Bukharan origin with a 2,000-year Central Asian heritage.

connections.name: Chabad of Tajikistan
connections.description: Chabad provides community services to the small remaining Jewish population.

Nepal.name: Chabad of Kathmandu
Nepal.description: Chabad of Kathmandu, Nepal, operates one of the most unique Chabad centers in the world, serving the thousands of Israeli and Jewish backpackers who visit Nepal annually, particularly after completing their military service. During the trekking season, the Kathmandu Chabad House hosts some of the largest Passover seders in the world, with over 1,500 participants. Founded by Rabbi Chezki and Chani Lifshitz, it also provides emergency assistance to travelers, including during the devastating 2015 Nepal earthquake when Chabad coordinated Israeli rescue teams. The center serves kosher meals, provides Shabbat services, and offers a "home away from home" for young Israelis on the popular post-army Nepal trekking circuit.

individuals.name: Rabbi Chezki Lifshitz
individuals.bio: Director of Chabad of Kathmandu since 1999. Coordinated major rescue efforts during the 2015 Nepal earthquake.

connections.name: Chabad
connections.description: Part of the global Chabad-Lubavitch network.

connections.name: Israel Defense Forces
connections.description: Serves as a gathering point for post-IDF travelers in Nepal.

Cambodia.name: Chabad of Phnom Penh
Cambodia.description: Chabad of Phnom Penh is the Chabad-Lubavitch center in Cambodia's capital, serving Israeli tourists, Jewish expatriates, and travelers. Cambodia has become one of the most popular destinations for young Israelis traveling after their mandatory military service, creating a significant seasonal Jewish population. The Chabad House in Phnom Penh hosts Shabbat dinners attracting hundreds of Israeli backpackers, provides kosher food, and serves as a community center. The Jewish presence in Cambodia connects to the country's complex history: Cambodia was devastated by the Khmer Rouge genocide (1975-1979) under Pol Pot, which killed nearly 2 million people. Jewish visitors have drawn parallels between the Cambodian genocide and the Holocaust, and Israeli organizations have been involved in supporting the Tuol Sleng genocide museum. The Chabad presence in Cambodia is part of Chabad's global network of over 5,000 centers in 100+ countries.

connections.name: Cambodian Jewish community
connections.description: Serves Jewish travelers, expats, and the small Jewish community in Cambodia.

connections.name: Southeast Asian Chabad network
connections.description: Part of the expanding Chabad presence across Southeast Asia.

Laos.name: Chabad of Vientiane
Laos.description: Chabad of Vientiane is the Chabad-Lubavitch center in the capital of Laos, one of the most remote Chabad outposts in the world. The center serves Israeli tourists and backpackers who visit Laos as part of their post-military service travels through Southeast Asia. Laos has become a popular destination for young Israelis drawn to its natural beauty, low costs, and adventurous atmosphere. The Chabad House provides Shabbat dinners, kosher food, and a community gathering point for Jewish travelers. Laos has a minimal historical Jewish presence, but the Israeli tourist community has created a seasonal Jewish population. Chabad's presence in Laos is part of its remarkable global network of over 5,000 centers, reaching some of the most unlikely corners of the world. The center exemplifies the Chabad movement's philosophy of serving every Jew regardless of location.

connections.name: Laotian Jewish community
connections.description: Serves the tiny Jewish community and travelers passing through Laos.

connections.name: Chabad-Lubavitch World Headquarters
connections.description: Part of the global Chabad network reaching even the smallest Jewish populations.

Sri Lanka.name: Jewish Community of Sri Lanka
Sri Lanka.description: The Jewish Community of Sri Lanka is a tiny community with a fascinating historical footprint. Jewish merchants were present in Ceylon (as Sri Lanka was known) for centuries, part of the broader Jewish trading networks across the Indian Ocean. The most notable aspect of Sri Lankan Jewish history is the Jewish cemetery in Colombo, dating to the Dutch colonial period (17th-18th century), which testifies to a more significant past Jewish presence. Today's community consists primarily of Israeli tourists (Sri Lanka has been a popular backpacker destination for Israelis after military service), expatriates, and a handful of permanent residents. Chabad of Sri Lanka has operated to serve Israeli tourists and the small resident community. The country's interaction with Israel has been complex - Sri Lanka was one of the first Asian countries to recognize Israel but has also supported Palestinian statehood at the UN.

individuals.name: Yaron Gal
individuals.role: Head of the Colombo Jewish community

connections.name: Israeli tourism
connections.description: Sri Lanka is a popular destination for young Israelis, creating a seasonal Jewish presence.

connections.name: Chabad
connections.description: Chabad operates in Sri Lanka to serve Israeli tourists and residents.

connections.name: Indian Ocean Jewish trading networks
connections.description: Jewish merchants were part of ancient Indian Ocean trading networks touching Ceylon.

Papua New Guinea.name: Jewish Community of Port Moresby
Papua New Guinea.description: The Jewish Community of Port Moresby is an extremely small congregation in the capital of Papua New Guinea, one of the most remote Jewish communities on Earth. The community consists of a handful of Jewish families, mostly expatriates involved in mining, development, aid work, and diplomatic service. PNG's Jewish presence dates to the colonial era when Jewish businesspeople and administrators worked in the territory. During World War II, Jewish soldiers serving in Allied forces were among those fighting in the Pacific theater in PNG. The community maintains minimal Jewish observance through informal gatherings and connections to Jewish communities in Australia. The existence of Jews in PNG highlights the extraordinary global dispersion of the Jewish people, with Jewish life maintained in even the most unlikely and challenging environments.

connections.name: Australian Jewish community
connections.description: PNG's Jewish community is supported by Australian Jewish organizations.

connections.name: Jewish diaspora
connections.description: Illustrates the extraordinary global reach of the Jewish diaspora.

Fiji.name: Jewish Community of Suva
Fiji.description: The Jewish Community of Suva, Fiji is one of the smallest and most remote Jewish communities in the world, numbering only a handful of families. Despite its tiny size, the community has maintained Jewish life in the South Pacific through holiday celebrations, Shabbat gatherings, and connections to larger Jewish communities in Australia and New Zealand. Fiji's Jewish history includes a small wave of Jewish settlers in the 19th and early 20th centuries, some involved in Fiji's sugar and trade industries. During World War II, Jewish refugees from Europe found temporary haven in Fiji. The community has been supported by Chabad emissaries and visiting rabbis from Australia. The existence of this community illustrates the global reach of Jewish diaspora, with Jewish life maintained even in some of the world's most remote island nations.

connections.name: Australian Jewish community
connections.description: Fiji's tiny Jewish community is supported by and connected to Australian Jewry.

connections.name: Chabad
connections.description: Chabad emissaries have provided religious services to Fiji's Jewish community.

Malta.name: Jewish Heritage of Malta
Malta.description: Jewish Heritage of Malta documents and preserves the traces of Jewish life on the Mediterranean island nation. Jews have lived in Malta since Roman times, with significant communities in Mdina and Valletta. The Knights of St. John expelled Jews in 1492 (coinciding with the Spanish expulsion), and the Inquisition operated in Malta until 1798. Despite persecution, some conversos (secret Jews) remained, and scholars have identified crypto-Jewish practices surviving into the modern era. Today Malta's Jewish community is extremely small (approximately 120 people), consisting mainly of expatriates. Heritage sites include the former Jewish street in Mdina, archaeological remains in Rabat, and the restored mikve (ritual bath). The Maltese-Jewish heritage has gained scholarly attention as part of the broader Mediterranean Sephardic diaspora story.

connections.name: Museum of Moroccan Judaism
connections.description: Both preserve Jewish heritage in Mediterranean countries.

connections.relationship: Connected to international Jewish networks

Luxembourg.name: Jewish Community of Luxembourg
Luxembourg.description: The Jewish Community of Luxembourg (Consistoire Isralite de Luxembourg) is the organized Jewish community in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, numbering approximately 1,500-2,000 members. Luxembourg's Jewish history dates to the 13th century, with Jews facing periodic expulsions and readmission throughout the Middle Ages. The modern community was decimated during the Holocaust when Nazi Germany occupied Luxembourg in 1940 - approximately 2,000 Jews lived in Luxembourg before the war, and over 1,000 were killed in the Holocaust. Today's community includes descendants of survivors, Sephardic Jews from North Africa, Israeli expatriates, and Jewish professionals working in Luxembourg's international financial sector. Luxembourg is home to major European institutions and banks, and Jewish business leaders play notable roles in the Grand Duchy's financial industry. The Luxembourg synagogue, rebuilt after wartime destruction, serves as the community's spiritual center.

individuals.name: Albert Aflalo
individuals.role: President of the Consistoire Israelite de Luxembourg

connections.name: Luxembourg Holocaust history
connections.description: Over 1,000 of Luxembourg's 2,000 Jews were killed during the Nazi occupation.

connections.name: Luxembourg financial sector
connections.description: Jewish professionals play notable roles in Luxembourg's international banking sector.

connections.name: European Jewish Congress
connections.description: Luxembourg's Jewish community is part of the European Jewish Congress network.

Monaco.name: Association Culturelle Isralite de Monaco
Monaco.description: The Association Culturelle Isralite de Monaco is the official Jewish community organization of the Principality of Monaco, serving the small but affluent Jewish population of this Mediterranean city-state. Monaco's Jewish community numbers approximately 500-1,000 people, many of whom are ultra-high-net-worth individuals attracted by Monaco's zero income tax policy and luxurious lifestyle. The community maintains a synagogue and organizes religious services and cultural events. Monaco's Jewish history includes the deportation of Jews during the Vichy period (World War II) despite Monaco being nominally independent. In 2015, Prince Albert II of Monaco officially apologized for Monaco's role in deporting Jews during WWII. The Jewish community includes prominent business figures in finance, luxury goods, and real estate. Israeli billionaires and businesspeople are among Monaco's most notable Jewish residents.

individuals.name: Francis Journo
individuals.role: President of the Monaco Jewish community

connections.name: Monaco Jewish community
connections.description: Serves Monaco's small but affluent Jewish community of approximately 1,000.

connections.name: French Jewish community
connections.description: Closely connected to the larger French Jewish community network.

Andorra.name: Jewish Community of Andorra
Andorra.description: The Jewish Community of Andorra is one of Europe's smallest Jewish communities, in the tiny Pyrenean principality between France and Spain. The community numbers only a few dozen families. Andorra's Jewish history is connected to the broader Sephardic experience on the Iberian Peninsula - after the Spanish and Portuguese expulsions of 1492 and 1496, some Conversos (Jews who converted to Christianity under duress) may have sought refuge in the remote Pyrenean valleys. In the modern era, Jewish residents are primarily businesspeople and professionals attracted by Andorra's tax advantages and mountain lifestyle. Andorra established diplomatic relations with Israel in 1995 and joined the United Nations in 1993. The community gathers informally for holidays and relies on neighboring Jewish communities in France and Spain for religious services and Jewish education.

connections.name: Andorran Jewish life
connections.description: One of Europe's smallest Jewish communities, numbering only a few dozen families.

connections.name: Barcelona Jewish community
connections.description: Andorran Jews have close ties to the larger Barcelona Jewish community.

Cyprus.name: Jewish Community of Cyprus
Cyprus.description: Ancient Jewish presence dating to Hellenistic times. After WWII, British detention camps in Cyprus held approximately 52,000 Jewish Holocaust survivors trying to reach Palestine. Today a community of several hundred.

individuals.name: David Alkalay
individuals.role: Head of the Jewish Community of Cyprus

connections.name: Cypriot Jewish history
connections.description: Jewish presence in Cyprus dates back to antiquity; the modern community numbers approximately 2,000.

connections.name: British Mandate detention camps
connections.description: Cyprus hosted British detention camps for Jewish refugees trying to reach Palestine in the 1940s.

Bosnia and Herzegovina.name: Jewish Community of Sarajevo
Bosnia and Herzegovina.description: The Jewish Community of Sarajevo (La Benevolencija) is one of the most historically significant and resilient Jewish communities in Southeastern Europe. Jews have lived in Sarajevo since 1565, when Sephardic refugees from Spain settled there under Ottoman protection. The community produced the famous Sarajevo Haggadah, a 14th-century illuminated manuscript that is one of the most valuable Jewish books in existence. During World War II, approximately 10,000 of Bosnia's 14,000 Jews were murdered. During the Bosnian War (1992-1995), La Benevolencija operated as a humanitarian organization providing aid to all Sarajevans regardless of ethnicity - one of the few organizations to cross all sectarian lines. Today approximately 700-1,000 Jews live in Sarajevo.

individuals.name: Jakob Finci
individuals.role: President of the Jewish Community of Bosnia and Herzegovina

connections.name: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee
connections.description: JDC has provided ongoing support to the Sarajevo Jewish community.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Represents Bosnian Jewry internationally.

North Macedonia.name: Jewish Community of Skopje
North Macedonia.description: The Jewish Community of Skopje represents the small but resilient Jewish community of North Macedonia. Before the Holocaust, approximately 7,762 Jews lived in Macedonia, primarily in Skopje, Bitola, and Stip. On March 11, 1943, Bulgarian occupation forces (acting under Nazi direction) rounded up and deported nearly all Macedonian Jews - 7,144 people - to the Treblinka extermination camp. Only 200 survived, a destruction rate of 98%. The post-war community reconstituted itself and today numbers approximately 200 people. The community operates the Holocaust Memorial Center in Skopje, opened in 2011, which is the first Holocaust museum in a former Yugoslav state. Macedonian Jewish heritage also includes the Beit Yakov Synagogue, which houses the community center.

individuals.name: Berta Romano Nikolikj
individuals.role: President of the Jewish Community of North Macedonia

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Represents Macedonian Jewry internationally.

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Collaborates on documenting the destruction of Macedonian Jewry.

Albania.name: Jewish Community of Albania
Albania.description: Albania is the only European country that had a larger Jewish population after WWII than before. Albanians of all faiths protected Jews based on the code of besa (honor). Approximately 200 Jews live in Albania today.

connections.name: Albanian rescue of Jews
connections.description: Albania is unique as the only European country with more Jews after WWII than before, due to mass protection.

connections.name: Besa code
connections.description: The Albanian code of Besa (honor) led Albanian Muslims to shelter Jewish refugees during the Holocaust.

Slovenia.name: Jewish Community of Ljubljana
Slovenia.description: The Jewish Community of Ljubljana represents the small but emerging Jewish community in Slovenia's capital. Slovenia's Jewish history includes a medieval presence in towns like Maribor (which had a significant Jewish quarter before the 1496 expulsion) and Ljubljana. During the Holocaust, the few hundred Jews in the territory were deported and murdered by the Nazis and their collaborators. After decades of near-absence, a small Jewish community has reconstituted itself in independent Slovenia, numbering approximately 100-200 people. The community was formally re-established in 2003 and operates cultural programs, religious services, and educational outreach. It marks a symbolic renewal of Jewish life in a country where it was nearly completely extinguished.

individuals.name: Andrej Kozar-Beck
individuals.role: President of the Jewish Community of Slovenia

connections.name: European Jewish Congress
connections.description: Connected to European Jewish communal networks.

connections.relationship: Slovenian member of WJC

Slovakia.name: Jewish Community of Bratislava
Slovakia.description: Bratislava (Pressburg) was one of the most important centers of Jewish learning in Europe. Rabbi Moses Sofer (the Chatam Sofer) established his famous yeshiva there. Before WWII 15,000 Jews lived there. Approximately 2,000 remain in Slovakia.

individuals.name: Moses Sofer
individuals.bio: Leading Orthodox rabbi known as the Chatam Sofer, head of the Pressburg Yeshiva, one of the most influential rabbis of the modern era.

connections.name: Chatam Sofer
connections.description: Bratislava was home to the great Rabbi Moshe Sofer (Chatam Sofer), a towering figure in Orthodox Judaism.

connections.name: Slovak Jewish history
connections.description: The community preserves the legacy of Pressburg (Bratislava), once a major center of Jewish learning.

Montenegro.name: Jewish Community of Montenegro
Montenegro.description: The Jewish Community of Montenegro (Jevrejska Zajednica Crne Gore) is one of the smallest Jewish communities in Europe, numbering approximately 300-500 members. Montenegro's Jewish history includes Sephardic Jews who settled in the Bay of Kotor after the 1492 Spanish Expulsion, establishing a community in cities like Kotor, Budva, and Podgorica. During World War II, Italian-occupied Montenegro provided some protection to Jews until the German occupation in 1943, after which Jews were deported and murdered. Today's community is active in preserving Jewish heritage, maintaining the Kotor Jewish cemetery, and educating about Jewish history in the region. Montenegro was the last European country to establish diplomatic relations with Israel (in 2006 when it became independent). The tiny community hosts cultural events and is involved in interfaith dialogue in the multi-ethnic Balkans.

individuals.role: President of the Jewish Community of Montenegro

connections.name: Sephardic heritage
connections.description: Sephardic Jews settled in Montenegro after the 1492 expulsion from Spain.
